## EXPONENTIAL
### for instance  an exponential random variable X with mean 3.
### we can find P(X > 4)

$$
\begin{align}
\mathrm{P}(X > 4) &= e^{(−1/3)(4)}
                  &= 0.9
\end{align}
$$  

###  It will fall between 2 and 3
$$
\begin{align}
\mathrm{P}(2 \le X \le 3) &= (1-e^{(−1/3)(3)}) - (1 - e^{(−1/3)(2)})
                  &= 0.14
\end{align}
$$  
###  will be no more than 2 i.e P(X <= 2)
$$
\begin{align}
\mathrm{P}(X \le 4) &= 1 - e^{(−1/3)(2)}
                  &= 0.33
\end{align}
$$ 
$$
\begin{align}
E(X) &= \frac{1}{\lambda}
                  &= 0.33
\end{align}
$$ 


$$
\begin{align}
VAR(X) &= \frac{1}{\lambda^2}
                  &= 0.3
\end{align}
$$ 
### getting x for prob 0.1

$$
\begin{align}
\mathrm{P}(X > x) &= e^{(−1/3)(x)}
\\ 0.1 &= e^{(−1/3)(x)}
\\ ln(0.1) &= - \frac{1}{2}x
\\ x &= 3ln(0.1)
\\ &= 2.7688
\end{align}
$$

                  &= 1 - \binom{10}{0}p^0(1-p)^0\\
                  &= 0.6787

$$ 




$$
\begin{align}
\mathrm{P} \left (X \le \frac { (b + a)}{2} \right) &= \left ( \frac { (b + a)/2 − a}{b -a} \right)\\
                  &= \left ( \frac { (b + a)/2 − a}{b -a} \right)
\end{align}
$$
